Tradition, Trivia, and the rise of the Turkey

12/12/2012

Fiona Parker expounds the myths of Christmas and reveals why York holds a special place in the history of British festivities.

Image by

By James Bithell

By now most of us know the basics of Christmas. We know the biblical story - that was drilled into our heads from the age of four - and we are well acquainted with our own personal traditions of overcooked vegetables, overdraft fines and over the top illuminations. Here are ten things you probably didn't know... 1. York was the first city in England to celebrate Christmas. Christmas in England began in York. Historians date English festive celebrations to 521 AD, when King Arthur visited the City on the 25th in order to thank Christ on his birthday for helping him win a battle against the Saxons. Next time you are walking around the seasonally illuminated City, spare a thought that this is where it all began. 2. Rudolph was created by a US Retailing Firm. The eternal yowling of children singing that well known chant about a little lonely deer may seem timeless, but believe it or not, there was once a time without it. In 1939, the book entitled Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer was published by Montgomery Ward under the authorship of Robert L. May. The firm had annually been buying and selling festive-themed colouring books before it was decided that creating their own book would be more profitable. Allegedly, "Rollo" and "Reginald" were considered before the reindeer was christened "Rudolph". This is just as well; Reginald would not have scanned quite as well in the popular children's song. 3. Whitney Houston's I Will Always Love You, is the Christmas single which held the number one spot for the longest. Although seasonally-themed hits such as Slade's Merry Xmas Everybody, have traditionally been favourites for securing the Christmas hot spot, Whitney proved a timeless classic will outlast even the remains of the family turkey. The 1992 single, which was part of the soundtrack for The Bodyguard, held its own for ten weeks including the Christmas week. Artists who have produced Christmas number ones which have been toppled after nine weeks include Queen, Al Martino and Wings. Such successes undeniably put Matt Cardle's three week reign to shame. 4. York Minster is the only Cathedral in the UK that puts mistletoe as well as holly on its high altar at Christmas. This ancient use of mistletoe is connected with Britain's Druid past, when mistletoe was seen as a symbol of friendship. The tradition of kissing under the mistletoe is thought to be linked to Norse mythology. In one tale, the goddess, Frigga, revives her son with a kiss after he has been shot with an arrow made of mistletoe. Early churches across England banned mistletoe for use in churches due to its connection with the Druids, who were considered sinful. The citizens of York, however, liked the plant and mistletoe services continued to be held, where the priest would hold a branch of the plant above a sinner's head and invite them to seek forgiveness. We've always been a pretty independent lot in York. 5. There is more than one Father Christmas. Most children in the UK take this view once Dad makes the fatal mistake of tripping over a trainer in the dark. However, Icelandic children spend their Christmas Eves wondering which mysterious gift-bringer will visit them. It would be dangerous to take bets, on account of there being thirteen in total. These jolly characters are known collectively as "The Yule Lads". Anybody who can speak Icelandic can have a lot of fun translating their names. "Spoon-Licker", "Gully Gawk", "Sausage-Swiper" and "Sheep-Cote Clod" are to name but a few. 6. Turkey hasn't always been the England's traditional Christmas dish. The largely overhyped, over-priced and often undercooked turkey can often seem to be as integral to Christmas dinner as the deadline of the Queen's speech. If we had been celebrating Christmas with the Celts however, we would have been treated to Wild Boar Stew. The Turkey did not begin to appear on the tables of England until the 16th Century. Henry VIII is thought to be the first English Monarch who celebrated Christmas Day with a turkey lunch. Goose also became a popular festive dish during the Victorian era, when working class families would set up "Goose clubs" in order to save up collectively to buy a goose at the end of the year. 7. Boxing Day gets its name from a charitable tradition. Despite popular belief, the "Boxing" in Boxing Day, has nothing to do with the high probability of a domestic row occurring the day after Christmas. The day was originally referred to as St Stephen's Day, when it was customary for British people to offer goods and money to those less fortunate than themselves. These donations would be placed in alms-boxes which were handed out at church services. After the service, the boxes would then be distributed to the poor and needy. It was traditional that gifts among equals were exchanged on Christmas Day, while beneficences from the rich to the poor were given out on the following day. 8. The largest secret Santa game at a single venue involved 1,270 participants. It can be difficult enough deciding what to buy for the family, but four years ago, the employees of one firm were asked to buy presents for people they had probably never met. In 2008, Boots UK Limited organised a mass secret Santa event at their headquarters in Nottingham. In 2011, ITV smashed this record, but only by using multiple venues. ITV staff and guests from locations all across the country exchanged 1562 gifts in total. The record attempt was a charitable event which raised money for the broadcaster's Text Santa appeal. 9. Crackers were invented by a man who was trying to boost the sales of his sweet business. In 1847, T.J Smith of London designed a sweet wrapper which resembled the modern day cracker. As he began to fight a sales slump, he started to wrap up mottos on tiny pieces of paper alongside the sweets. Smith was inspired to include the "crackle" element of the cracker, then named a "Cosaque", when he took note of the crackling of a log as he placed it on a fire. The size of the cracker was increased in order to hold the banger mechanism and the sweet was eventually replaced with a small gift. Smith's son, Walter, continued to work on his father's design by adding paper hats and varied patterns. By this time, rival cracker companies were already competing against the family business. 10. Christmas presents are opened on different days all over the world. While a number of countries such as the UK, the USA and Japan choose to wait until the 25th December, the children of Holland open their gifts on St Nicholas's Eve - the 5th December. In Belgium, Germany, Czech Republic and several other European countries, gifts are opened on the 6th. Meanwhile, children in several Catholic countries such as Spain and Mexico have to wait until the Epiphany - the 6th January. Photo Credits in ascending order: wader, etmeyer, wattpublishing and Speculum Mundi. This article was amended at 11:05 on 15th December 2012.
